mods.abstract:
The Hundar Manuscript Collection is a set of canonical Tibetan Buddhist manuscripts housed in the village of Hundar, Nubra valley, Ladakh. At least one volume is identified as a collection of sūtras (mdo mangs).
Dating to the 17th or 18th century, the collection's precise historical circumstances, patrons, and compilers remain unknown. It was recently documented by the Tibetan Manuscript Project Vienna (TMPV).
Detailed information on the collection's transmission or preservation is lacking. The best-documented volume is a mdo mangs, which closely matches volume 94 (mdo sde; Ge) of the Phug brag Kanjur, sharing its pagination and marginal titles. This parallel suggests both derive from a common source, illustrating the complex transmission and circulation of canonical texts in the region.
